docs.lead_paragraph: "LET me tell you about Commerce quickly," Representative John R. Kasich, the chairman of the House Budget Committee, said Thursday evening on "The MacNeil-Lehrer News Hour." "We, for example, did in fact kill programs in Commerce. The advanced technology program, which gives millions of dollars to big corporations for research, is eliminated. The U.S. Tourism and Travel Administration, the Economic Development Administration. We have 300 economic development programs in the Federal Government. We wiped them out." The next morning, at a news conference on the budget, Senator Tom Daschle, the Democratic minority leader, had this to say: "The concern, I guess, that many of us have in particular has to do with the significant tax increase that this budget resolution has for many working families. For 12 million working families, there will be a $21 billion tax increase over the course of the next seven years."

headline.main: The Nation; First Comes the Smoke (then Mirrors) in Budget's Maze

docs.lead_paragraph: THIRTEEN years after Susan Psillos was sexually abused at the age of 4 by four teen-age boys in her neighborhood in Centereach, she continued to remember the incident. She was living in Wading River and was on her way to having several abusive relationships, some involving rape, because, she said, she "thought that was normal." "I remember as a child crying and thinking, 'Oh, that happened,' until we moved away," Ms. Psillos recalled. "I also remember trying to commit suicide in the fourth grade by taking a bottle of Vitamin E pills. Childhood secrets of trauma are not healthy."

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR Loretta Cullen of Waterford, who has been hospitalized many times over the past few years, finding a doctor proved to be almost as big a challenge as her illnesses. "A patient's problem is not just with the insurance companies. It starts with finding a doctor, period," Ms. Cullen wrote recently in a letter to a newspaper. "Our community has too few physicians, and all are overbooked or not taking new patients. If you're fortunate enough to receive an appointment, it will be for a month or two later, even though your problem is now."

headline.main: Where Have All The Doctors Gone?

docs.lead_paragraph: It is a question of pain. Everyone agrees there must be pain for everybody, though something in the manner of those who talk of pain's necessity hints that they themselves expect exceptions will be made in their cases. Since they are mostly members of Congress and its political courtiers, their expectations are probably well founded. This is a class highly skilled at insulating itself from such common miseries as the health-insurance nightmare and the vanishing- pension phenomenon.

docs.lead_paragraph: The contract with school bus drivers that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proudly unveiled on Thursday could save the city $400 million over the next five years, as the administration contends. But it is a measure of Mr. Giuliani's reputation for toughness at the bargaining table that many union leaders and labor experts actually saw the contract as a hint of his possible weakness. That seemingly contradictory reaction is a result of the high expectations the Mayor raised when he set the most important goal of the talks with the drivers: the elimination of costly job guarantees that he said were un-American.

docs.lead_paragraph: Never mind that the House Republicans' Contract With America sounds like it was written by corporate chieftains. Never mind that Senator Bob Dole tried to score points with blue-chip businesses this week by broadening a proposal intended to reduce civil lawsuits. And never mind that the public has long identified big business as a core Republican constituency. Republican leaders want everyone to believe that theirs is not the party of big business. "Big business doesn't have a party," Haley Barbour, the Republican national chairman, said flatly.

docs.lead_paragraph: INSURANCE is the kind of business where there are exceptions to every trend. While commercial liability policies have been costly for insurers hit with claims for environmental cleanups, a few companies have done very well. And in thriving lines of business, such as medical malpractice insurance, there are some companies that manage to lose their shirt.

headline.main: Market Place; In insurance brokering, Acordia is bucking the no-growth trend.

docs.lead_paragraph: The White House locked horns with Congressional Republicans in the strongest terms yet today, denouncing their plans for balancing the Federal budget by the year 2002 as feckless and economically risky efforts to keep an "arbitrary campaign promise" and insisting that they drop their proposed tax cuts for the wealthy as a condition of negotiations. With President Clinton away in Moscow, a parade of senior Administration officials appeared in the White House briefing room to accuse the Republicans of making "false promises" by pledging to cut taxes and spending so deeply. They warned that proposed cuts in the growth of the Medicare and Medicaid health care programs, could leave millions of children uninsured and impoverish the elderly and disabled. And they offered no hints of compromise or help.

headline.main: Administration Rejects Plan As Based on False Promises

docs.lead_paragraph: Pete Domenici, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, proposes to cut nearly one out of every three dollars that the Government spends on domestic programs. He proposes to slash tax credits for poor workers and subsidies for the arts and humanities. He proposes to eliminate the Commerce Department and scores of Federal programs. The Domenici plan would cut Medicare by 15 percent and Medicaid by about 30 percent. Alarming? Outrageous? The frightening fact is that by current Washington standards, Mr. Domenici is the voice of budget moderation. His House counterpart, John Kasich, issued a seven-year plan yesterday that, by cutting taxes by $350 billion and raising defense by $70 billion, is more than $400 billion harsher on non-defense programs.

docs.lead_paragraph: Stepping up the political war over Medicare, the Clinton Administration today rejected many of the leading options being discussed in Congress to shore up the finances of the health-insurance program for the elderly. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, Dr. Donna E. Shalala, told the Senate Finance Committee that the Administration did not want to raise the eligibility age for Medicare, increase premiums or other costs for beneficiaries or reduce payments to hospitals serving large numbers of poor people.

headline.main: Congress's Medicare Plans Rejected by Clinton Aides
